did.abstract: Estela Bravo is an American-born documentary filmmaker whose award-winning films focus on Latin America, and especially Cuba, where she has lived since the early 1960s. Bravo’s bi-cultural perspective informs her work, as do her progressive political convictions and humanist philosophy. This collection includes 1,365 videotapes ( Umatic and Betacam format), along with a number of films on DVD and on 16mm and 35mm reels. Almost all of Bravo’s documentaries are represented in the collection, although for some there may be only a copy of the feature film or a small number of film clips. The documentary Fidel: The Untold Story has the largest presence and its interviews are a highlight, with such figures as Arthur Schlesinger, Ramsey Clark, Alice Walker, Philip Agee, Edward Heath, George McGovern, Ted Turner, and others, including many well-known Cuban revolutionary fighters and government officials, as well as counterrevolutionaries such as the notorious Orlando Bosch. Other films, such as The Cuban Excludables, Miami-Havana, and Americans in Cuba, also have significant representation within the collection. Because all of the materials arrived with serious condition issues, the process of mold remediation, repair, and digitization has been initiated and is ongoing. Only a portion of the footage is currently viewable. Access copies of digitized footage are available in the Tamiment Library reading room. A number of Bravo full-length documentaries have been acquired and may be seen at NYU’s Avery Fisher Center for Music and Media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Estela and Ernesto Bravo Collection contains full-length features and film footage from documentaries directed by Estela Bravo over the past thirty-five years. A total of 1,365 videotapes (U-Matic and Betacam format), along with a number of films on DVD and on 16mm and 35mm reels, have been donated by the Bravos.

Estela Bravo’s body of work is focused on the human consequences of historical events and on attempts to achieve social justice throughout Latin America, Africa, the Caribbean and the United States. Many of her films tell the story of Cuba since the Revolution and its relationship with the United States and with other countries; she also documents the tragedy of the missing children from Argentina’s “dirty war;” abuses inflicted by the Pinochet regime in Chile; the assassination of Maurice Bishop in Grenada; poverty and hunger resulting from Latin American debt: and the struggles to end apartheid in South Africa. Some of the films are of historic cultural events such as Silvio and Pablo in Argentina (1984), which shares a massive concert held in Buenos Aires at the end of the military dictatorship, featuring two of Cuba’s most popular musicians, Silvio Rodriguez and Pablo Milanes, performing songs that had previously been forbidden in Argentina.

Not all of Bravo’s films are represented within the collection. For some of the documentaries, there is only a copy of the feature-length film, and, for others, only film clips. The most extensive representation is from Fidel The Untold Story (and the follow-on film, Anecdotes about Fidel). There are more than four hundred pieces of footage as well as copies of the films themselves. Among the highlights of this material are interviews with such notable individuals as Arthur Schlesinger, Ramsey Clark, George McGovern, Alice Walker, Harry Belafonte, Philip Agee, Ted Turner, Edward Heath, Jorge Risquet, Ricardo Alarcon, Vilma Espin, Angela Davis, and many others, including counterrevolutionaries such as the notorious Orlando Bosch.

Other films that have a strong presence in the collection are Americans in Cuba, personal stories of individuals who came to Cuba and have made their lives there; The Cuban Excludables, which reveals the plight of many Cubans who came to the US during the Mariel boatlift and who were indefinitely detained in harsh and abusive conditions; and Miami-Havana, a film that illustrates the tragic consequences of restrictions on travel and communication between Cuba and the US.

In addition to Bravo documentaries, there is footage that was not included in any feature film. It may have been shot with a potential film in mind, or just because an interesting event was occurring or someone important was available to speak with the Bravos. For example, there is an interview with Mikis Theodrakis, a Greek songwriter/composer and opponent of repressive Greek regimes. Theodrakis is a longtime supporter of Cuba and of Fidel Castro. There is footage from Brazil, including an interview with Luis Carlos Prestes (1898-1990) who was a Brazilian revolutionary and leader in the Brazilian Communist Party.

Although a large part of the collection consists of interviews, there are also scenes of important events, marches, demonstrations, and performances; battle footage; historical clips from Cuba’s State Council archives; speeches by Fidel Castro, Nelson Mandela, and others; and a good deal of background footage (b-roll) used in the finished films. Some of the material may be seen in more than one documentary, as older clips often provide background and context for a subsequent film. A good example is the use of footage from the 1985 film, Missing Children, in the 2007 documentary, Who Am I? The Found Children of Argentina.

Because almost all of the videotapes arrived at the Library in very poor condition (mold, binder hydrolysis, brittle or broken tape), viewing of the footage has only been possible once a video has been remediated/repaired and digitized. This process is ongoing, with just over 270 pieces of film currently viewable and accessible to researchers.

All of the currently digitized material is described in the finding aid; adding entries for video not yet digitized is underway and will continue until all items are listed. Determining context and content has been based on box and reel annotations; viewing of full-length films to identify events, individuals and locations; historical research; and input from Estela and Ernesto Bravo. The descriptions of videos that have not yet been digitized will often contain phrases in quotation marks. These are the annotations copied from the original cassette boxes and are often the only clues to the content at this time. As digitized versions become available, more accurate descriptions will be possible. Footage that has not yet been associated with a specific feature film may be found in the collection’s Series XXVII. It should be noted that most of the footage is undated; specific dates are listed if they appeared on the cassette annotations or were inferred from the film's content. All currently digitized material is accessible in the Tamiment reading room.

In a 2015 donation, materials such as periodicals, programs, playbills and related items were added to the collection. They may be found in Series XXIX: Ephemera and Publications. Also included were many transcripts and partial transcripts of interviews associated with the film Fidel The Untold Story. They may be found in Series VII and include some individuals for which there is no film footage; e.g., Walter Sisulu and Kalema Moutante.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Estela Bravo (1933- ) is an American-born documentary filmmaker whose award-winning films focus on Latin America, and especially Cuba, where she has lived with her husband, Ernesto Mario Bravo, since the early 1960s. This unique bi-cultural experience informs, enriches, and distinguishes her films. Gary Crowdus, founder and editor of Cineaste magazine characterized her as "both an American, one whose progressive political convictions and humanist sentiments were formed during the anticommunist hysteria which gripped the US in the Fifties, and as an assimilated Latin Americanist who has lived in Cuba for decades." Described as a sensitive filmmaker and skilled interviewer, Bravo finds the essence of social problems and political issues by talking with individuals directly involved, and is often able to elicit their innermost feelings. The films reflect compassion, empathy, and a sincere desire to reveal the human drama behind the larger events of the day.

Bravo's documentaries have been shown throughout Latin America and around the world, at international film festivals, and at retrospectives honoring her work. Her films have also been viewed on PBS (US), CBC (Canada), Channel 4 (UK) Canal Plus (France) and on many other television networks.

Born in Brooklyn on June 8, 1933, Estela Bravo is the youngest of three daughters from a working class family of European immigrants. Her mother died when she was only 12. Her father, Phillip Segall, was a Union man whose ideas influenced her greatly. Estela worked for the Furriers Union while studying sociology at night at Brooklyn College. She helped organize a group called Students for a Peaceful World and, in 1953, as their representative, attended the 3rd World Student Congress in Warsaw, Poland, where she met Ernesto. They married in January of 1956 and for several years she worked in Argentina as a teacher and, later, for an airline company. When, in 1963, Ernesto was asked to join the faculty of the Medical School of the University of Havana, the Bravos moved to Cuba. There, she worked at the cultural institution Casa de las Americas where she was involved in programs centering on folk and protest music, and, at the same time, earned a degree in History from Havana University. Estela moved on to developing children's television programs and creating short documentaries based on archival footage dealing with such figures as the Rosenbergs, Malcolm X, and Paul Robeson. (The scripts were written by Ernesto.) In 1980, Estela Bravo completed her first major documentary, Those Who Left, the story of Cubans who left the island after the triumph of the Revolution. Films she has made since that time are listed in the Filmography below.

Ernesto Mario Bravo (1929- ) was born in Argentina on April 7,1929. In 1951, while a University student in Buenos Aires, he was abducted from his home by Peronist police, held and cruelly tortured for twenty days before being released, in part because of a massive student protest and strike. When Ernesto and Estela met, he was still recovering from his injuries. Having received a PhD in Chemistry from the University of Buenos Aries, Ernesto was asked to teach Biochemistry at the Medical School of the University of Havana. In addition to his teaching career, Ernesto has written a number of books, including Modern Medicine in Cuba (1995) and Development within Underdevelopment: New Trends in Cuban Medicine (1998). He has also been a collaborator with his wife on her many documentary films.

Estela and Ernesto Bravo continue to make films and to travel the world. In 2014, they were honored in South Africa by the Mandela Foundation, made several trips to Argentina, visited their three children and grandchildren in the US, and released films about Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Commander Juan Almeida, along with an update to their 2007 film, Who am I? The Found Children of Argentina.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: Estela and Ernesto Bravo sent several donations of their films and videos between 2012 and 2013. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2012.044, 2012.061, 2012.062, and 2013.014. In May of 2015, Estela Bravo's sister delivered an addition to the collection to Angela Carreno, Head of Collections Development for the NYU Division of Libraries. The accession number associated with this addition is 2015.031; these materials have been incorporated into Series VII on the film Fidel or into a new series for ephemera and publications (Series XXIX), as appropriate.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements Note
phystech.p: A number of films in this collection have been digitized. Researchers must use access DVDs to view this material. Existence of access copies is indicated in the descriptive information for each individual recording. Additional information about material that has not been digitized may also be found at the entry level. Please contact the library to determine if films in this collection have been digitized and are ready for immediate use.

Researchers interested in using materials that have not been digitized must request an access copy. These requests are free of charge and can be made in anticipation of a visit. Films in this collection are in extremely poor condition, and researchers are limited to 5 digitization requests per year. Because of the condition issues, digitization of films may take up to 6 months to complete. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu for more information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: Upon receipt of this collection, Tamiment Library discovered that a large number of films were mold infested, and separated these materials for immediate stabilization and preservation treatment. Subsequent assessments revealed mold in more of the videos, as well as binder hydrolysis and other condition issues, making it impossible to view any of the original film footage. Working with the Preservation Department and several vendors specializing in remediation of digital media, the process of repair and digitization was initiated and is ongoing.

Film footage in this collection has been associated with the full-length feature in which it appears. In the containers that arrived from Cuba, there were packing slips that roughly listed feature films with which each box's contents were associated; however, the immediate removal of many of the seriously moldy films meant separation from this limited information. The cassette cases and/or the cassettes themselves, were sometimes annotated with the film name or had some other annotations suggesting film or footage content. A few had small handwritten notes inside.

Much of the information concerning specific footage content and associated feature film(s) has been reconstructed to the best of the archivist's ability through analysis of container annotations, research, and consultation with the donors. Material has been incorporated into the series that best represents the context of its use. (Note that some of the footage may relate to other series or be represented in multiple full-length feature films in this collection.) The descriptions of video cassettes that have not yet been digitized will often contain phrases in quotation marks. These are the annotations taken from the cassette boxes. As digitized versions of the videos become available, descriptions are being updated.

An addition to the collection was received in May of 2015 (accession 2015.031). These materials have been incorporated into Series VII on the film Fidel or into a new series for ephemera and publications (Series XXIX), as appropriate and can be found in boxes 59 and 60.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The 16mm and 35mm films donated by the Bravos have been separated out and are maintained in the Preservation Department.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Video recordings in this collection are arranged by the film in which they appeared. Within each series videos are grouped by interviewee or by subject. Series XXVII contains unidentified footage as well as footage that was not created for a specific film.

There is a series entry for every Bravo film for which NYU has been given the full-length film and/or footage from the film. Estela Bravo has directed additional documentaries which are not included in the series descriptions for this collection.
The final series in the collection contains a variety of periodicals and ephemera.

did.unittitle: Series I: Americans in Cuba, Those Who Came

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: After the Cuban Revolution, some Americans remained in Cuba; others came afterwards for various reasons and decided to stay. Among them were the following:

Elfriede Mahler (1917-1998), an American dancer who arrived in Havana in the summer of 1960 and remained. She spent much of her life in Guantanamo, founding the province’s first professional dance company, Danza Libre.

Marjorie Moore (1920-2003) was born in the US and studied at Columbia University. In 1946, she married a Cuban named Luis Rios and they moved to Cuba with their daughter Pamela in 1950. She remained in Cuba for the rest of her life. She was a teacher, headed a brigade of teachers in Cuba’s Literacy Campaign and, in 1962, joined the English Department of what is now the Medical University of Havana. She is most known for her work in English for Medicine.

Lorna Burdsall (1928-2010) came to Cuba in 1955 as the wife of a Cuban revolutionary. Ms. Burdsall was raised in New London, Connecticut, trained with Martha Graham and studied dance at the Julliard School. In 1953 she met a young Cuban, Manuel Pineiro, who was studying business administration at Columbia. They married in New York but he left for Cuba to join Castro’s forces shortly after their wedding. She joined him in 1955 and lived in Cuba for the rest of her life. Burdsall taught at the National Dance School and was a founding member of Conjunto Nacional de Danza Moderna, which she eventually directed. Burdsall was with the company for nearly 20 years and created numerous works reflecting the spirit of the Cuban people. In 1977 she became the national director of dance and modern dance advisor to the Minister of Culture. She mentored and inspired generations of Cuban dancers and brought influences from Western dance that have since been taught to many young Cubans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Estela Bravo speaks to a number of Americans who stayed in Cuba and, tells their stories in her 43-minute film. This series contains footage of Bravo's visits with women such as Elfriede Mahler; Marjorie Moore; Lorna Burdsall; Lois Kroehler, a missionary, music teacher and peace advocate who came to Cuba in 1949; Jean [McEvoy]; Ellen Rosensweig, who is interviewed with her husband and children and comments on the differences between her life in Cuba and her visits to see her family in California. Footage from this film contains one-on-one interviews, performances, discussions in the street or in other venues, and scenes of the various locations where the women live.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This 38-minute film documents a trip to Havana associated with Camp Kinderland, a progressive Jewish camp. More than a hundred US citizens, ranging in age from 16 to 80, tour schools, a cigar factory, synagogues and also Cuba's monument to the Rosenbergs near Revolution Square.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Camp Kinderland is a summer camp for boys and girls aged 8 through 16, located in Tolland, Massachusetts. The camp was founded by members of The Workmen’s Circle/Arbeter Ring in 1923 at Hopewell Junction, New York, and promotes progressive social values through its cultural programs. Many camp alumni remain committed to various socialist and anti-war causes, sometimes under the Kinderland banner.

Series IV: Cuba/South Africa: After the Battle

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In October 1975, South Africa invaded Angola intending to defeat the leftwing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and could have succeeded had not 36,000 Cuban soldiers poured into Angola. For 13 years, Cubans and Angolans fought side by side against South African forces. In addition, the Cubans trained African National Congress (ANC) guerrillas and rebels fighting for Namibian independence against the occupying South Africans. After a decisive battle at Cuito Cuanavale (1988), Pretoria accepted Cuban demands and withdrew unconditionally from Angola and agreed to UN supervised elections in Namibia. Fidel Castro’s commitment to the struggle against apartheid was one of the underlying motivations for his intervention in Angola. Nelson Mandela later said that the Cuban victory “destroyed the myth of the invincibility of the white oppressor… [and] inspired the fighting masses of South Africa… Cuito Cuanavale was the turning point for the liberation of our continent – and of my people – from the scourge of apartheid.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: After the Battle relates the history of Angola’s struggle for independence and Cuba’s pivotal contribution to its success. Filmed on location in Angola, South Africa, Namibia and Cuba, this 58-minute documentary examines the motivations and consequences of the war. In addition to copies of the full-length feature, this series contains combat footage, archival material, and interviews with Cuban and South African soldiers and with grieving families of those who were killed.
In 1991 the film won a Silver Apple Award for Best Film in War and Peace category, National Educational Film and Video Festival, Oakland, California.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: More than 125,000 Cubans left the fishing port of Mariel in 1980 bound for the United States. A number of them were prison inmates or mental patients who had been released to join the boat lift. Although some were held for having committed serious crimes, and not released, many were eventually freed. But any of the Mariel Cubans who committed a crime once in the US were immediately returned to INS custody after they served jail or prison sentences. Many had been picked up on petty offenses such as shoplifting, drunk driving, or marijuana possession. The US contended that any Cuban refugee who had not become a citizen or legal resident could be detained indefinitely after completing a jail term for even the smallest crime. The lack of normal relations with Cuba made it impossible to send them back.

US District Judge Marvin Shoob in Atlanta ruled in 1983 that this detention was unconstitutional, but a panel of appellate judges overturned his decision. Shoob, in an unusual posture for a federal judge, spoke out in favor of the detainees and disagreed with the assumption that they were all violent criminals.

In an agreement signed in 1984, Cuba consented to the return of about 2,500 detainees but the deportations were cut short because of broadcasts by US government-sponsored Radio Marti into Cuba. Riots in 1987 at prisons in Georgia and Louisiana led to the renewal of the deportation agreement and a promise of hearings for the detainees. Attorneys for the Cubans, however, were not allowed to call witnesses, to cross-examine adverse evidence, or to see the full contents of their clients’ files. The hearing process could take many years and the Cubans were being held in conditions considered deplorable by national and international human rights groups. In addition, many of the Cubans who were eventually deported were forced to leave American families behind. This was the situation at the time the Bravos filmed The Excludables.

Though flawed, the review panels did eventually free many of the prisoners. In 2005, twenty-five years after the Cubans left Mariel, the US Supreme Court ruled that open-ended detention of Mariel Cubans was illegal. At that time there were 750 still in detention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: In addition to copies of the full-length feature, the series footage includes interviews with a variety of individuals including US District Judge Marvin Shoob; Wayne Smith, former head the US Interests Section in Havana; and Dennis (Denny) McLain, a former American baseball player who was convicted of embezzlement and spent time in prison with the Cuban detainees. Other interviewees include lawyers and human rights activists, INS and Coast Guard employees; correctional officers and other prison staff, and the detainees themselves, along with family members. Of particular interest are interviews with Dr. Bolivar Martineau, deputy warden and chief medical officer at the Atlanta Penitentiary. Martineau was accused by prisoners and staff of physical abuse, including using Thorazine and Haldol to control the detainees and conducting experiments on them with various drugs.

In addition to the interviews, there are news clips, footage from the prisons, interviews with the American families of some of the detainees, and scenes from Cuba, as the detainees arrived home and were reunited with their Cuban families. Some of the material is duplicative and there are background visuals and many shots of leaving and arriving planes.

Note that the interviews with Bolivar Martineau and Denny McLain were arranged and funded by 5th Estate Canadian Broadcasting System who used the footage for a period of time and then turned it over to the Bravos for their film.
In 1995, The Cuban Excludables won a Special Jury Prize at Cinefest, San Juan, Puerto Rico; and One World Award, Best Overseas Production on British TV, European Community BBC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The 2001 documentary Fidel: The Untold Story combines a history of the Cuban revolution with a more personal story of its leader, Fidel Castro. Footage from the Cuban State Council Archives and various news sources, as well as exclusive interviews with historians, public figures, close friends, and with Castro himself, provide a glimpse into the life and personality of the charismatic Cuban leader. Interviewees such as Alice Walker, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Arthur Schlesinger, Ramsey Clark, Ted Turner, Nelson Mandela, Charles Rangel, George McGovern, Philip Agee, and many others share personal anecdotes along with political and historical perspectives.

Because so much of the interview footage for Fidel: The Untold Story could not be included in the initial feature-length film, the Bravos decided, in 2009, that they should make another film. Anecdotes about Fidel incudes portions of twenty-four interviews and expands on the stories about Fidel. The anecdotes come not only from well-known Americans such as Harry Belafonte, Jesse Jackson, Angela Davis, Hank Aaron, Sydney Pollak and others, but also from many Cubans who are not so well known in the US. Among them are government officials and friends of Fidel such as Juan Almeida, Melba Hernandez. Alfredo Guevara, Jorge Risquet, Antonio Nunez Jimenez, Alicia Alonso, Angela Castro, and Aleida Guevara.

This series contains copies of both films. It includes not only complete interviews and portions of interviews highlighted in the two films, but also interviews that are not seen in the films. Examples include an interview with Hortensia Bussi de Allende, the widow of Salvador Allende, and one with American lawyer Victor Rabinowitz.

In 2001, Fidel: The Untold Story was selected for the Toronto Film Festival and won an award for "Distinguished Achievement for Excellence in Documentary Filmmaking" at the Urbanworld Film Festival, New York.

Note about State Council footage: The clips in each piece of footage often represent a wide date range. Some of the footage is dated '1998' which reflects the date the material was obtained, not the actual date of the events. The actual dates are not recorded.

bioghist.p: Ramón Eusebio Castro Ruz (1924 - ) is the eldest male Castro sibling, brother of Fidel and Raúl Castro. Using his skills in both farming and engineering, Ramón manufactured an alcohol-based fuel for Cuba during a gasoline shortage. After the revolution, Ramón Castro abandoned the family farm as it became legal property of the state. He dedicated himself to the study of agriculture and is chiefly responsible for many of Cuba's agricultural initiatives since the revolution.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Francisco Gonzales Aruca (1941-2013) was a Cuban-American economist. He was a student at a Jesuit school in Havana at the time of the Cuban Revolution. He became part of the counterrevolution soon after joining Manuel Ray's counterrevolutionary organization, Movimiento Reolucionario de Pueblo (MRP). He and was arrested in 1961 by the Castro government and sentenced to thirty years in prison. He escaped weeks later and hid in the Peruvian embassy, eventually reaching the US via Ecuador and Colombia. Aruca rethought his politics after he made his way to Georgetown University, where he earned degrees in economics. The U.S. government permitted family visits between Cuba and the United States starting in 1979. Cubans began traveling to the island via Marazul Charters, a company started in the New York area by Aruca with a goal of bringing families together. When he opened an office in Miami in 1986, company offices were firebombed and a Human Rights Watch report on right-wing intimidation in South Florida singled out Aruca as a leading victim. In 1991 he began hosting a radio program in Miami, "Ayer en Miami" (Yesterday in Miami), considered controversial and referred to as revolutionary and a game changer at the time. Through his program, Aruca became a public figure who was hated by some and loved and admired by others in the Miami area. The New York Times, in a public profile in 2006, described Aruca and his program as an unusual "pro-Castro radio show" in South Florida. Aruca always called for the normailization of US-Cuban relations.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carlos Alberto Libanio Christo, O.P. (1944), better known as Frei Betto, is a Brazilian writer, political activist, liberation theologist, and Dominican Friar. As a liberation theologist, he has been involved in various international efforts to support an understanding between Marxism and Christianity. During a visit to Havana in the 1980s, he held frequent and lengthy interviews with Fidel Castro and, subsequently, wrote the book, Fidel and Religion, which is said to have improved relations between Castro's government and the Catholic Church.
Frei Betto and Fidel Castro have remained friends and Betto is a frequent visitor to Havana.

In 2013, he was selected by UNESCO as the 2013 recipient of its International Jose Marti Prize for "his exceptional contribution to building a universal culture of peace, social justice and human rights in Latin America and the Caribbean." The prize was awarded in Havana on the 160th anniversary of Jose Marti's birth.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Orlando Bosch Avila (1926-2011) was a Cuban-American pediatrician, violent extremist, and head of Coordination of United Revolutionary Organizations [CORU], which in 1978 the FBI described as "an anti-Castro terrorist umbrella organization."

Bosch, who attended the University of Havana's medical school, interned at the University of Toledo in Ohio. After returning to Cuba, he opposed the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista and later supported Castro. By mid-1960, however, Bosch became disillusioned with the direction taken by the Cuban revolution and took his family to Miami.

In Miami, Orlando Bosch became a violent opponent of the Castro government. In 1968 he was sentenced to 10 years in US federal prison for bombing ships engaged in trade with Cuba. After being paroled in 1972, he resumed terrorist attacks. The FBI noted that in June 1974 he admitted sending letter bombs to Cuban embassies in Canada, Peru, Spain and Argentina. After the bombing of a Cubana Airlines plane in 1976, in which 78 people died, Bosch was arrested and tried by the Venezuelan government and later acquitted. He, along with another exile leader, Luis Posada Carriles, was also suspected of involvement in the assassination of Chilean former minister Orlando Letelier in Washington, DC in 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The digitized version of this footage is contained on four access DVDs. In the first, a WQBA radio host makes and announcement the Channel 4 news is attempting to make contact with several people to share with them information about their families in Cuba. The next two, very brief, portions are background footage from the WQBA radio station. The final DVD contains the interview with Orlando Bosch. This interview also features a discussion with Bosch's wife, who is Chilean. She talks about how the two met and how her relationship with Bosch has shaped her views about Cuba and the Cuban people.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Peter G. Bourne (born 1939 in Oxford, England) is a physician, anthropologist, biographer, author and international civil servant. After graduating from medical school at Emory, he entered the US Army and, among other duties, spent a year in Vietnam. His various careers include serving in the administrations of both Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter. In 1979, he became an Assistant Secretary-General at the United Nations. Beginning in 1980 Bourne had been, on a part-time basis, chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at St. George's University Medical School in Grenada, West Indies. In 1998 he moved to Grenada and became Vice Chancellor of the University. In 2003 Bourne left Grenada and returned to Washington, D.C. He was appointed as a Visiting Senior Research Fellow at Green Templeton College at the University of Oxford and divided his time between the US and the UK.

Building on a long standing interest in the Cuban health care system and relationships established during several visits to the country, Bourne published a biography of Fidel Castro, Fidel - a biography of Fidel Castro in 1986. In 1995 as chairman of the American Association for World Health he directed a year-long foundation-supported study "Denial of Food and Medicine: The Impact of the US Embargo on Health and Nutrition in Cuba" that looked at humanitarian issues surrounding the US Embargo on Cuba.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In 2000, a major controversy revolving around the custody and immigration status of a 6-year old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, involved the governments of the US and Cuba; Gonzalez's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez Quinanta; Gonzalez's other relatives in Miami and in Cuba; and Miami's Cuban American community.

Elian's mother, Elizabeth, drowned in November 1999 after leaving Cuba with her boyfriend and son in an attempt to reach the US. Initially, the US Immigration and Naturalization Service placed the boy with maternal relatives in Miami, who wanted to keep him in the US in opposition to his father who wanted him returned to Cuba. A ruling by the federal district court that only Elian's father could petition for asylum on the boy's behalf was upheld in the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. The US Supreme Court declined to hear the case. Because the Miami relatives continued to hold Elian, in defiance of court rulings, federal agents were ordered to seize the boy. In June of 2000, he returned to Cuba with his father.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Melba Hernandez Rodriguez del Rey (1921-2014) was a key participant in the Cuban revolution and later a politician and diplomat. After graduating from the University of Havana School of Law in 1943, Hernandez initially worked as a Customs attorney. She was one of the two women, the other being Haydee Santamaria Cuadrado, among the 131 rebels involved in the assault on the Moncada Barracks on July 26, 1953. Sentenced to 7 months in prison, she later assisted Fidel Castro, who remained in prison until 1955, in smuggling out the small portions of text that would be assembled into the manuscript of History Will Absolve Me. Hernandez was with Castro during his Mexican exile and participated in planning the rebel leader’s return to Cuba by the boat Granma in 1956. She joined the fighters with the Third Front under Juan Almeida Bosque.
Hernandez served as Cuban Ambassador to Vietnam and to Democratic Kampuchea (now again Cambodia) and was a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Gabriel Garcia Marquez (1927-2014), considered one of the greatest writers of the 20th century, was a Colombian novelist, short story author, screenwriter, and accomplished journalist. He received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982. Known best for his 1967 novel, One Hundred Years of Solitude, Marquez was a master of the literary genre known as magical realism. He was also known for his strong support of left-wing causes. For more than thirty years, the US State Department denied him a visa to travel in the US. According to the New York Times, this was partly because of his longtime friendship with Fidel Castro. (The travel ban was rescinded in 1995 by President Bill Clinton.) The bond between Marquez and Castro is highlighted in the 2014 Bravo film, A Conversation with Garcia Marquez About his Friend Fidel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The footage begins with a 14-minute interview with Wayne Smith followed by almost four minutes of still photos, first of Fidel and Wayne Smith, then followed by what appear to be photos in George McGovern's office, including photos of McGovern with Bill Clinton and McGovern with Castro. At around 18 minutes, the interview with McGovern begins.

In this interview, George McGovern speaks about his maiden speech in the Senate (1963) on the subject of US-Cuba relations and about his continued support for normalization. He tells a little about himself and then talks about his initial meeting with Fidel (fourteen hours over two days). He discusses the Miami Cuban community and their control of American foreign policy towards Cuba.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo (1934-2012) was a former Cuban revolutionary who later became a dissident. After an attempted armed uprising against Fidel Castro, he spent 22 years in Cuban prison. Once released, he moved to Miami. Later, he founded Cambio Cubano, a centrist group that promoted dialogue and reconciliation among Cubans of all political backgrounds. He returned to Cuba in 2003 and was allowed to stay despite his frequent criticisms of the government. He died in Havana in October of 2012.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Gianni Minà (1938- ) is an Italian journalist, writer and television host. He has collaborated with both Italian and foreign newspapers and magazines; produced hundreds of reports for the Radiotelevisione Italiana; designed and presented television programs, as well as produced successful documentary films. In 1987 he interviewed Fidel Castro for the first time. This 16-hour encounter was part of a documentary "Un Dia con Fidel" (A Day with Fidel). The interview also served as the primary source for Fidel Racconta il Che (Fidel Talks About Che), a report in which Castro discusses the heroic deeds of Ernesto Che Guevara. In 1990, a second interview between Minà and Castro was held. The two interviews were brought together in the book Fidel.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Danielle Émilienne Isabelle Mitterrand, nee Gouze (1924 – 2011) was the wife of French President François Mitterrand. A member of the Resistance in World War II, Mme. Mitterrand was a longtime human rights activist. “I often stood even farther to the Left than my husband, because I was free of the restraints that come with being in government,” she told Der Spiegel in 2005. As France’s First Lady, she created the France-Libertes Foundation in 1986. A long time supporter of the Castro government, Mme Mitterrand was also a supporter of the African National Congress and the anti-Apartheid movement.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Joseph Moakley (1927-2001) was a U.S. Congressman from Boston's South Side. After serving in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II, Moakley went to the University of Miami and obtained his law degree from Suffolk University Law School in Boston in 1956. Moakley was an elected member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives and Senate before winning a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives in 1972. He rose to become chairman of the powerful House Rules Committee and served in the House until his death in 2001.

bioghist.p: Robert Alan Pastor (1947-2014) was a member of the National Security Council Staff during the administration of Jimmy Carter. With responsibility for US policy toward Latin America and the Caribbean, Pastor participated in the Carter administration’s efforts to improve relations with Cuba. Pastor also played a role in the negotiation of the Panama Canal Treaties. In a display of anger at those Treaties, Senate Republicans later prevented Pastor’s confirmation as US ambassador to Panama after his appointment by President Clinton in 1994.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Victor Rabinowitz (1911-2007) was a prominent American lawyer who, with his partner Leonard B. Boudin, defended a generation of American activists on the left. In his 1996 memoir, Unrepentant Leftist, Mr. Rabinowitz explained that from 1942 until the early 1960s, he was a member of the CPUSA. In 1960, the Cuban government requested Rabinowitz to represent Cuba in legal cases in the United States. In 1964, he won the Sabbatino case in the US Supreme Court, which upheld Cuba’s sovereign right to nationalize American companies in Cuba. A decade later, Rabinowitz defended Chile’s right to nationalize US firms. The firm Rabinowitz, Boudin, Standard, Krinsky & Lieberman continues to represent Cuba. bioghist.p: Charles Bernard "Charlie" Rangel (1930- ) is the U.S. Representative for New York's 13th congressional district. A member of the Democratic Party, he is the second-longest currently serving member of the House of Representatives, serving continuously since 1971. As its most senior member, he is also the Dean of New York's congressional delegation. Rangel was the first African-American Chair of the influential House Ways and Means Committee. He is also a founding member of the Congressional Black Caucus.
Rangel has been a supporter of easing the US embargo and has expressed concerns about the activities of certain elements of the Cuban exile community in Miami.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. (1917-2007) was an historian and presidential advisor. After attending Harvard University, Schlesinger served in the wartime Office of Strategic Services, the intelligence service of the Joint Chiefs of Sgtaff. Winning a Pulitzer Prize for his study of the presidency of Andrew Jackson in 1946, Schlesinger later taught at Harvard University. It was his advocacy for the Presidential candidacies of Adlai Stevenson, and later John F. Kennedy, that brought Schlesinger US national prominence. From 1961 to 1963, Schlesinger served in the White House as advisor and occasional speechwriter to President Kennedy. Latin America was among his areas of responsibility and Schlesinger opposed plans for what became known as the Bay of Pigs operation. His books A Thousand Days (1965) and Robert Kennedy and His Times (1978) remain among the most influential chronicles of the Kennedy era.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Maximo Francisco Repilado Munoz, known as Compay Segundo, (1907 – 2003) was a Cuban trova guitarist, singer and composer introduced to much of the world on Ry Cooder's Buena Vista Social Club album.

In the 1950s he became well known as the second voice and tres player in Los Compadres, a duo he formed with Lorenzo Hierrezuelo in 1947.(It is from this partnership that his nickname comes - the second compadre.) Los Compadres were one of the most successful Cuban duos of their time. Greater international fame came later, in 1997, with the release of the Buena Vista Social Club album, a hugely successful recording which won several Grammy awards. Compay Segundo appeared in the film of the same title, made subsequently by Wim Wenders.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Wayne S. Smith (1932- ), an academic, author and former US diplomat, obtained degrees from the La Universidad de las Americas (BA), Columbia University (MA) and the George Washington University (PhD). He served in the United States Marine Corps from 1949 to 1953 and saw combat during the Korean War. He joined the Department of State in 1957, serving in the Soviet Union, Argentina and Cuba. In 1961 he was appointed by President John F. Kennedy to serve as the Executive Secretary of his Latin American Task Force.

Smith served as Chief of the U.S. Interest Section in Cuba from 1979 to 1982. He was skeptical of the US embargo and promoted dialogue with the Cuban administration. He left the Foreign Service in 1982 and was appointed as Senior Associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. In 1985 he became Adjunct Professor of Latin American studies at the Johns Hopkins University and since 1992 a Senior Fellow at the Center for International Policy in Washington.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note

Released in 1959, he held positions within the Communist Party of Cuba and the Cuban government, including representing Cuba as ambassador to the Soviet Union and Great Britain.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dudley Joseph Thompson (1917-2012) was a Jamaican Pan-Africanist lawyer, politician and diplomat. He served in the Jamaican House, the Senate and as a Cabinet Minister under Prime Minister Michael Manley. He also represented Jamaica in many international forums.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Rev. Lucius Walker, Jr. (1930-2010), a Baptist minister, founded Pastors for Peace after being wounded by Contra rebels during a fact-finding mission to Nicaragua in 1988. Rev. Walker opposed the US embargo on Cuba, challenging the economic and travel blockade with annual caravans bringing US citizens and humanitarian aid to the island in defiance of US law. In 1993 participants gathered 100 tons of aid, including a Little Yellow School Bus which was seized by the US Customs Service in Laredo, Texas. For 23 days, caravanistas stayed on the bus, holding a hunger strike and launching an international campaign until they and the bus were released to go to Cuba. At the invitation of Fidel Castro in 2000, Rev. Walker formed and headed the committee that made it possible for US students from underserved communities to study medicine at the Latin American School of Medicine in Havana.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Cuban Institute of Cinematographic Art and Industry (ICAIC) was established by the Cuban government in March 1959, after the Cuban Revolution. It was designed to produce, distribute and exhibit films and related work following the revolution; its goal was to use film as a powerful mass communication medium to mobilize and educate people, improve the quality level of Cuban films, and to reach a wide public.

Cuba's official film institution, the ICAIC has produced feature and documentary films. The institute also has an extensive film library, and its movie house, the Charles Chaplin Theatre, regularly shows both world and Cuban cinema.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carmen Gloria Quintana Arancibia (1968- ) is a Chilean woman who became, to many Chileans, a symbol of hope for democracy in Chile, receiving an embrace and encouragement from Pope John Paul II.

On July 2,1986, Quintana, along with a young photographer, Rodrigo Andres Rojas de Negri, were participating in a student protest in Santiago. They were attacked and beaten by a patrol of military police, then soaked with gasoline and set on fire. De Negri died of his burns. Gloria suffered second and third degree burns over 62% of her body; she was critically ill and was moved to a hospital in Canada. Although she survived, Gloria remains badly disfigured from her burns. When the Pope visited Chile in 1987, she returned and was able to meet with the pontiff in Santiago.

A little over a year after the Pope's visit, Pinochet's reign of torture and terror came to an end. In January 1991, a military tribunal found the military patrol leader guilty only of negligence for having failed to get medical help for de Negri. In 1993, however, he was sentenced to 600 days in prison for his responsibility in the burning death of de Negri and serious injuries suffered by Quintana. In 2000, the government was ordered to pay her 251.7 million pesos (US $500,000) in compensatory damages.

Gloria Qunitana has held teaching posts and worked with SENAME, the national Chilean organization for the protection of the rights or minors and adolescents. In 2010, she emigrated to Canada to pursue a PhD in psychology at the University of Montreal. She also serves as scientific attache at the Embassy of Chile in Canada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This 43-minute documentary captures the turbulence of Chile under the Pinochet dictatorship, tracing the story of Carmen Gloria Quintana and her journey, in 1987, back to Chile to see the Pope. In addition to footage of the Pope's visit and the ongoing protests, there are interviews with Quintana and many others. Among the voices captured are those of elites, particularly young people, who supported the status quo and felt that the protests were unnecessary.

Among the many awards won by this film were Best Documentary on Current Affairs, San Francisco International Film Festival; Gold Plaque Award, Chicago International Film Festival; and Best Documentary, American Film Institute Global Village Festival, New York.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Nelson Mandela visited Cuba in 1991, a year after being released from prison, and met Fidel Castro. It was the beginning of a close friendship between two exceptional men. Their friendship was based on shared views, mutual respect, and on the gratitude felt by Mandela for Cuba's assistance in Angola and its support for ending aparthied in South Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is a full-length feature of the film Mandela and Fidel. The film begins with Nelson Mandela's attendance at the Namibian independence celebrations in March of 1990, only a month following his release from prison. He meets with Cuban officials and expresses his gratitude for Cuba's assistance in the war in Angola and for their role in Namibia's achievement of independence. The next year Mandela visits Cuba and, with Fidel Castro at his side, is feted everywhere. The documentary follows the relationship for several more years including Castro's attendance at Mandela's inauguration in 1994 and Fidel's visit to Robben Island to see where Mandela had spent so many years. The two men's strong affection for each other is evident throughout the film.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: At the time of this film, Nelson Mandela was President of the African National Congress. He visited Cuba while on a Latin American tour. Among the tour goals was to persuade such countries as Brazil, Mexico, and Venezuela to maintain sanctions against South Africa's white minority government and to support Mandela's call for a national unity government in Pretoria to supervise elections and constitutional reform. No lobbying was needed to gain Cuba's support. The visit represented a meeting between two revolutionaries who had long admired each other but never met.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Mandela in Cuba documents Nelson Mandela's visit to Cuba in July of 1991. He attended the celebrations marking the 38th anniversary of the 1953 attack on the Moncada garrison. Among the most interesting moments is Mandela's response to a reporter from the Miami Herald who asks, on behalf of the exiles in Miami, if Mandela would comment on human rights in Cuba.
The series contains a copy of the full-length feature as well as footage shot during the visit.

Series XXI: Operation Peter Pan: Flying Back to Cuba

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In 1960, rumors were spread In Cuba, including a faked legislative draft, that the revolutionary government was planning to take children from their parents and put them in military schools or send them away for communist indoctrination. Between 1960 and 1962, as many as 14,000 children were subsequently flown out of Cuba, without their parents, in a joint effort orchestrated by the US State Department and the Catholic Church. While, in many cases, parents were later able to rejoin the children, some never saw their families again and many never again saw their homes in Cuba. Some of the children went on to achieve success in the US but many had to endure traumatic experiences and difficult adjustments. Once in the US, some were placed in orphanages or camps, and some suffered abuse. This episode is often referred to as Operation Peter Pan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This 57-minute documentary tells the story of Operation Peter Pan using interviews as well as historical footage found at the National Archives. While a number of Peter Pan "children" are interviewed, the film centers on a group of five who, after almost fifty years, make their first trip back to the island. Estela Bravo follows them as they explore their past and help bridge the emotional and political divides between the US and Cuba.

Operation Peter Pan: Flying Back to Cuba was selected as Best Documentary Feature at the 2011 Havana Film Festival New York. It also won First Prize at the Festival Internacional de Cine Politico, Buenos Aires, Best Documentary at the 7th Human Rights International Festival in Bolivia, and the Coral Award at the International Festival of New Latin American Cinema.

bioghist.p: Ana Mendieta (1948 – 1985) was a Cuban American performance artist, sculptor, painter and video artist. Born in Havana, Mendieta and her sister were sent to the US as a part of Operation Peter Pan in 1961. Mendieta's work, generally autobiographical and focused on themes including feminism, violence, life, death, place and belonging, may be found in many major public collections, including the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Whitney Museum of American Art, New York, Museum of Modern Art, New York, Art Institute of Chicago, Centre Pompidou, Paris, Musée d'Art Moderne et Contemporain, Geneva, and Tate Collection, London.

Much controversy surrounds her death on September 8, 1985, when she fell from her 34th floor apartment in Greenwich Village. She shared the apartment with her husband of eight months, the minimalist sculptor Carl Andre. He was accused of her murder, but was tried and acquitted in 1988.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carlos Muniz Varela (1953-1979), along with his sister, was sent from Cuba to the US in 1961 as a part of Operation Peter Pan. As a university student in Puerto Rico, Carlos Muniz became involved in the fight for Puerto Rican independence In 1974 he was one of a group of young Cubans in Puerto Rico and the US who questioned their parents' hostility to the Cuban revolution; they founded a magazine, Areito, which promoted the normalizing of US-Cuba relations. In 1977 he and others organized a group to visit Cuba, a trip that would lead to the creation of the Antonio Maceo Brigade which brought together young Cubans to demand normalizing of relations between the US and Cuba. In addition to organizing other Cuban trips, Muniz and a friend set up Viajes Varadero, a travel agency to facilitate these trips. Attempts at promoting dialog with Cuba created many enemies within the counterrevolutionary groups and, on April 28, 1979, Muniz was ambushed while driving in San Juan and shot several times. No one has been charged with his assassination.

Series XXVI: Who Am I: The Found Children of Argentina

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This 2007 documentary provides a continuation of the Bravo's 1985 film, Missing Children, tracing the stuggle of families of those disappeared during the Argentine "Dirty War" (1976-1983) to discover the fate of their loved ones and to recover the kidnapped children of those who were killed. The organizational center of the film is the women's group known as the " Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo" who gained worldwide recognition for their weekly demonstrations in the center of Buenos Aires. Their decades-long campaigns included, not just demonstrations, but also widespread posting of photographs, presentations in school classes, and modern DNA analyses. (Geneticists from the US worked with the Grandmothers, storing blood samples from family members in the National Genetic Data Bank until the grandchildren could be located and accurately verified.) These efforts have resulted in the restoration of proper identities to 115 young adults, who have, in most cases, reestablished connections with their biological relatives.

When this film was initially released the number of found children was 88, but a new version, released in 2014, provides updates, including the news that "Grandchild 114" is Guido, the grandson of Estela Carlotto, one of the founders and president of the Grandmothers organization. She had been searching for him almost forty years. And the Grandmothers continue finding additional "children."

The film includes interviews with the young people and with people who knew their parents. Other footage shows the end of the trial and sentencing of the junta leaders; the final statements of two particularly notorious torturer-murders (a police official and a prison guard); and portions of a speech by the late Nestor Kirchner (President of Argentina from 2003-2007) in which he apologizes for ignoring the issue of the disappeared during the previous years of his political life.

Among many 2007 accolades, Who Am I? won the Coral Award, International Festival of New Latin American Cinema; Telesur Award, Best Documentary on Latin America; Best Documentary, Toronto Film Festival; Audience Popularity Award, Cinesul Film Festival, Rio de Janerio; and the Elizabeth Cady Stanton Award, High Falls Film Festival, Rochester, NY "to a filmmaker of high principles for her dedicaton to tough, life-affirming documentaries."

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Luciano Nieves was a Cuban exile living in the US. In 1975, he was ambushed and murdered in the parking lot of Miami Childrens Hospital, after visiting his 11-year-old son. Nieves had been speaking out in support of negotiations with the Cuban government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note

This tape includes footage of the widow of Luciano Nieves; Felipe Rivero (a "terrorist" involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion); and Bryan O Walsh, the Catholic priest who oversaw the removal of 14,000 Cuban children in Operation Peter Pan.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The majority of the nearly 1 million current Cuban exiles living in the United States live in and around the city of Miami. Other exiles have relocated to form substantial Cuban American communities in Union City and West New York, New Jersey (known as Havana on the Hudson); North Carolina; Los Angeles, California; and Palm Desert, California. The term "escoria" refers to a statement made by Fidel Castro about Cuban exiles, who once said, "Anyone who wants to leave Cuba can do so" and declared that those who were leaving the country were the escoria (scum).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The first approximately 12 minutes involve Panchita Fajardo (Dr. Francisca Rivera Arocha), one of the early female physicians in Cuba. Her son, Major Manuel Piti Fajardo Rivera, was also a physician. He was killed in the mountains during the Revolution; her daughter-in-law was a professor of medicine who worked with Ernesto Bravo. There is interaction between Estela Bravo and Ms. Fajardo and also moments with Raul and Fidel Castro, and Carlos Rafael Rodriguez.

The next part of the film begins with Fidel Castro speaking about energy for a few minutes, followed, from 00:13:45 - 00:26:00, by a short film produced by the Atomic Energy Commission of Cuba titled Create the Future. The film is in Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Beginning with stills of a wedding, the remainder of the footage is a young man speaking in Spanish. He talks about attacks and assassinations carried out by far-right wing, anti-Castro terrorist groups, mentioning a bombing of the Cuban Mission to the UN carried out by a New Jersey-based group Omega 7. He also speaks about the larger context of these groups and discusses the assassinations of Orlando Letelier, Carlos Muniz, and Eulalio Negrin. He describes the origin of these organizations and suggests that many of their actions are motivated by anti-Castro propaganda from the US.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is footage of an on-the-street interview of three [Dominicans] (per annotations on box). Estela Bravo speaks with them, in Spanish, about various topics including the Reagan administration and the experience of the Spanish-speaking population in New York. They are very critical of Reagan and his policies which they consider anti-Latin. The talk about the economic situation in the US, lack of representation, lack of support for poor communities, and the difficulty of uniting Latin Americans in the US because they come from so many different countries. Other concerns include the difficulty of organizing for more rights when working too busy working at low wage jobs. Bravo asks their opinions about American policies re: Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras, etc. They also discuss how the US addresses problems such as drug addiction and violence.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia -- People's Army (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia - Ejercito del Pueblo, FARC-EP and FARC) is a guerilla organization that has been involved in armed conflict in Colombia since 1964. The FARC claims to be an army of peasant Marxist-Leninists with a political platform of agrarianism and anti-imperialism. It has been known to employ a variety of military tactics and, in order to fund its operations, has used such means as illegal mining, extortion, kidnapping to ransom, taxation, and distribution of illegal drugs.

The National Liberation Army (Ejercito de Liberacion Nacional, ELN) is another group involved in the ongoing Colombian armed conflict. This organization advocates a composite Communist ideology of Marxism and Liberation Theology. A well-known member of the group was Colombian socialist and Roman Catholic priest, Camilo Torres. During his life he tried to reconcile revolutionary Marxism and Catholicism.
(4/2015: Note that, since 2012, Cuba has been hosting peace negotiations between the FARC and the government of Colombia.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: An interview (in Spanish) with Raul [Herrera/Viera], a FARC member, who discusses the history of the organization and its goals, as well as its view of US imperialism and US policies in Latin America after the Cuban Revolution. He talks about guerilla movements and the use of violence, and about a war for peace and social and economic reform. He also speaks about Camilo Torres as a hero in Colombia.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Luis Carlos Prestes (1898-1990) was a Brazilian revolutionary. He led rebels on a three-year trek (beginning in 1924) through the interior of Brazil in an attempt to spark a rebellion in the coutryside. The attempt failed, but he became a romantic figure in Brazil and went on to lead the Brazilian Communist Party. He was imprisoned after a 1935 uprising, but released after World War II, and served for a short time as a senator.
